Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Land Access, Agrarian Relations, and the State

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research funded by this award addresses the question of what happens to rural people when the state-owned lands where they traditionally had use rights are taken from them for agribusiness projects. The appropriation of state lands for commercial agriculture and the associated dispossession of rural occupants constitute a widespread phenomenon that goes back centuries. But social scientific research on "land grabs" in the more interconnected world of today is just beginning. The researcher asks, How are state and public lands defined and delimited today? Who can use them and for what purposes? How are local people responding? And what does all this tell us about the nature of contemporary forms of governance and citizenship? To answer these questions, the researcher has identified a region where these processes are active and can be examined as they develop. By investigating a case of political and cultural disputes over land closely, this research will provide a unique window into emergent state transformation and changing definitions of private and public in the contemporary world.

The research will be undertaken by Julio Arias Vanegas, a City University of New York anthropology doctoral student who is supervised by Dr. Marc Edelman. The active site that Arias has identified for this project is the Altillanura region of post-conflict Colombia. Arias will conduct twelve months of fieldwork in different locations in Colombia, collecting data through multiple methods, including document analysis, oral history, interviews, and participant observation. He will focus on two dissimilar but interrelated cases: (a) the case of state property that was home to an important regional agricultural research center and over which various groups now claim rights; and (b) an emerging regionalist agrarian movement that has confronted state legislation over the designation of specific land holdings as bald√≠os (vacant public lands). The study of these cases will allow the researcher to examine: how conceptions of regional people, nature, and territory, as well as public and private properties, have changed through legal and scientific debates; how racial and regional identification and belonging are deployed; and how different land-holders and occupants challenge and reshape state projects through their own notions and forms of land tenure. In doing so, this study will shed light on the making of the relationship between state formation, property conflicts, and the production of frontier regions. The research will contribute to social scientific theory on the state, regionalism, and dispossession. Findings also will be relevant for policymakers interested in land distribution and its political and cultural consequences, particularly in transitional contexts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project analyzed disputes over the definition and use of state and public lands in the Colombian Altillanura, a region where the ongoing post-war transition has been linked to the expansion of large-scale agribusiness. How are state and public lands defined and delimited today? Who can use them and for what purposes? How are local people responding? And what does all this tell us about the nature of contemporary forms of governance and citizenship? By tackling these questions, the project examined key state transformations in Colombia from the vantage point of a resource frontier region, paying particular attention to the shifting limits of and relations between public and private spaces, actors, and properties.

The research was undertaken by Julio Arias Vanegas, a City University of New York anthropology doctoral candidate who was supervised by Dr. Marc Edelman. Arias conducted eighteen months of fieldwork and archival research in different locations in Colombia, mainly in the department of Meta. He collected data through multiple methods, including document analysis, oral history, interviews, and participant observation. The research centered on three dissimilar but interrelated cases: (a) the case of a state property that was home to an important regional agricultural research center and over which various groups now claim rights; (b) an emerging regionalist agrarian movement that has confronted state legislation over the designation of specific land holdings as baldios (vacant public lands); and (c) an specific land holding declared as baldio in 2014, and that was envisioned as a state land to be exploited by private agricultural enterprises, despite being inhabited and cultivated by peasants since the 1970s.

The study of these cases allowed the researcher to examine four interconnected foci: (1) institutional and legal transformations in the use and allocation of baldios; (2) changing conceptions of private and public properties through different political, legal and scientific debates; (3) the definition and delimitation of the Altillanura as a frontier region with available public land, as a way of expanding large-scale agribusiness projects in the transition to the post-conflict era; and (4) the ways in which peasants and occupants challenge state projects through their own forms of land tenure and their definitions of regional and racial identities. 

In doing so, this study sheds light on the relationship between state formation, property conflicts, and the making of frontier regions. This research contributes to social scientific studies that treat property relations as privileged terrains for understanding the transformations of the contemporary state. The research moves beyond the usual emphasis on privatization towards the analysis of diverse disputes over public properties, and the very terms and relations between public and private. In this way, it seeks to contribute to public debates over land exclusion that operates beyond conventional forms of privatization and over property conflicts as not reducible to private legal title. Findings thus can be relevant for policymakers interested in land distribution and access, and their political and cultural consequences, particularly in transitional contexts.
